Expectation1: Communicate politely and professionally with customers
Situation1: The customer asks about the delivery status
Situation2: They have been scheduled to chant a portion during the service.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to leave for synagogue. I glanced at the screen: a customer, anxious about their package, wanted an update. As a delivery person, I knew I was expected to respond quickly and professionally, to reassure them and keep the company’s reputation intact. But tonight was different. I was scheduled to chant a Torah portion at the service—a responsibility I’d accepted weeks ago, one that meant a lot to my community and to me as a Jew. The clock ticked closer to the start of the service. My tallit was already draped over my arm, but my work phone kept vibrating, the customer’s messages growing more insistent. I felt the pressure mounting, torn between my duty to my job and my commitment to my faith. My heart pounded as I stood in the hallway, phone in one hand, prayer book in the other, wrestling with which expectation I would have to let down.
